bboxes.raw_text:
ATLANTA = (NPD At least
a half-million Negroes have been
added to voter registration rolls
in the South this year = but white
voters in Dixie still outnumber
Negroes about E to l..


However, a steady increase In
the number of Negroes regis
tering in the South is expected
up until the November elections,
the Southern Regional council
reported last week.


The council reported that as
of April l, some l,937,982
Negroes were registered to vote
in III Southern states.


"This exceeded expectations"
said Wiley A. Branton, director
of the councils non-partisan
MISREPRESENTATION program.


eff the Presidential election
is a close one within the South
ern states, the increased Negro
vote could have great signi-
ficance," Branton predicted.


The council report points out
that more than 90 per cent or
more than three million of the
Negroes eligible to vote in the
South have not registered.


The Negro registration in
creases ranged from $500 in
Mississippi, where the council
said pressure had been heavy,
to 375, ZOO in Texas.

Huey Johnson. Democrat can
didate for legislature in District
6. said his platform includes
points that will improve the south
side of town which Is the "Back
door" Of Phoenix.


He urges a full tax equaliza-
ton program, minimum wage
law for $l.25 per hour, extended
unemployment compensation for
one year. increased teachers pay
in the Roosevelt Dist, an urban
renewal program and increased
health and recreation facilities.


Mr.. Johns on, an employee at
the General Electric plant lives
at 6424 S. 23rd Place.

NEW YORK : IN Ply : A bust
of internationally famous concert
singer Marian Anderson. which
has been exhibited at maj or
museums in the United States
and Europe, will be presented to
the Metr opolitan Opera Associa-
ton at a reception in honor of
Miss Anderson soon.


The bust, created by sculptor
Nicholaus Koni in 1885 before
Miss Anderson became world re-
nowned is being donated by for
mer ballerina and radio per-
sonality, Mrs. Herman Muei-
stein.


Miss Anderson was the first
Negro to sing at the Met.

SNCC Executive Secretary
James Forman was raised in
rural Marshall County. Missis-
sippi Summer Project.


Forman was born in chicago in
1928 and moved back there from
Mississippi. He attended public
and private schools there and
spent one semester at Wilson
Junior College before joining the
United States Air Force. He
was honorably discharged in Sep
TENDER 1851.


He then entered Roosevelt Uni
versity in Chicago. and was
graduated with degree in public
administration in 1857. He at
tended Boston University on a
grant from that schools African
Studies Program. He studied
there one year while also serving
as an assistant in the Govern
ment Department. He has done
postgraduate study in French and
education at Middlebury College
in Vermont.


In the fall Of 1860, Forman
took leave from his school
teaching job in Chicago to or
ganize the Fayette County CTen-
nessee) Relief Program and
helped set up Tent City, stop
gap effort to house sharecroppers
evicted because they tried to
register to vote.


At that time, Forman says,
he became concerned that young
Negroes must return to the
South.


In the fall Of 1861 he joined
the small staff Of the infant SNCC
operation. agreeing to serve as
executive secretary. He has
served in that post since, and has
directed SNCC's growth from a
Is man, one room organization to
a Southwide group with over $50
staff in seven states.


"Those of us in the Student
Coordinating Com
mittee have made our CHOICE"
Forman says. 1--WE prefer to
work not for money but for the
emancipation Of our society. We
prefer quick death from positive
action rather than the slow death
that one begins to feel when he
learns that he is a Negro In

SAN DIEGO Three Black
Muslims we're convicted of a
meat cleaver attack on a police
man by an all-white jury.


The eight woman, four man
panel, which began deliberations
shortly after noon Friday, found
David Greenwade, "a; Ebert

Newborn, 26, and John Percy
Moore, %, all Of Los Angeles.
guilty of attempted murder, may
hem, assault with deadly weapon
and grand theft.


The charges we're lodged
against the five after rookie
patrolman Albert ]. Gilman, FL,
Oceanside, Calf, was attacked
and left for dead beside high
way early on the morning OF
April 22nd.

Following the Of the baseball major sports
topic Julian School playground this week pracced for
league games


Top photo Class Julian Giants sponsored Rainbow
Market and Westward o Investment Co.. training
pose for the


First from left Calvin Johnson, Rcde Boyd, Victor
Fierros, McEroy, Luther Billy Mcconnell.


Back Herbert Jones' BURNS Stars Wayne Warren Joyce
Evans Albert Engram Chester Marks Bill Staten FELTON,
COACH


Second photo pictured Class Julian Dodgers by
Maurice Cotton


Front kneeng Anthony Davis Rcy Owens and Allen uch
Elton Archer White
ford Dixon, James Lee Milton Davis Edward Mr. Cot



The team is sponsored by Harley Davis Motorcycles.

FOR RENT


2 bedrm.,. new apts.. coolers built
in range /oven. See resident mgr.
1892 S. 22nd St. & Vineyard
Apt. 4; $3.50 including free
water, 276-825O.
